FacilityName: Helena Agri-Enterprises, LLC - Urbana, IN Facility
FRS_Method: GPS CARRIER PHASE STATIC RELATIVE POSITION

_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, Terrorism, and High winds.
_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: Emergency shutoff valves and pull away protection
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Storage tanks and ancillary process piping, liquid pump, valves, and transfer hoses.
_prev_prog_2.Description:
The Operations Manager implements the Risk Management Plan (RMP) and Risk Management Program (RMPr) for the Storage & Handling of anhydrous ammonia at this facility and is assisted by other Helena staff as directed. The RMPr describes the Accident Prevention Program that includes Safety Information, Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Maintenance, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigation, and Emergency Response.  Equipment included under this covered process includes (1) 8,000-gallon stationary

pressure vessel, and ancillary liquid pumps, piping, and valves; (8) 1,500-gallon nurse tanks; and (30) 1,000-gallon nurse tanks. Helena personnel perform the transfer of anhydrous ammonia from the storage tank to the nurse tanks in accordance with the Operating Procedures provided in the RMPr.



Helena receives anhydrous ammonia by a Contractor that transports the anhydrous ammonia with a commercial tanker truck. The commercial tanker truck is temporarily parked on the Facility property while the anhydrous ammonia is transferred to the on-site pressure vessels.  The transfer process from the commercial truck is performed by the commercial tanker truck operator (Contractor). Helena does not own or operate the commercial tanker truck. The vendor is responsible to Helena for complying with relevant operation and training procedures and documentation. At a minimum, the vendor must (1) have in place and certify compliance with applicable and relevant DOT and OSHA regulations, (2) make available to Helena and EPA upon request any contractor-related documentation necessary to demonstrate compliance, and (3) certify that it has in place emergency shut-down procedures for ammonia unloading operations and that its OSHA and DOT programs comply with federal, state, and local regulatory requirements. Further, Helena will provide a copy of its Contingency Plan and RMPr for review upon request by the Contractor.

_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: This is a non-responding facility and it coordinates its response activities with the LEPC and local Fire Department. Notification information and procedures are provided in its Contingency Plan.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



The Facility has submitted this updated electronic RMP in compliance with the provisions of the Clean Air Act 112 (r) as codified by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency at 40 CFR Part 68. Standards codified by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration at 29 CFR 1910.119 are not applicable to the operations at this facility because the Facility is operated as a retail operation and is exempt from the OSHA standards. However, the OSHA standards at 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, are applicable and are included in the Risk Management Program (RMPr) document that is implemented by this Facility.



This electronic submittal provides conservative estimates of the offsite consequences of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia from the Facility located at 211 E 500 N, Urbana, IN 46990. The electronic RMP summarizes the policies and procedures implemented by the Facility to minimize the likelihood of an accident.  The electronic RMP also summarizes the actions that the Facility has taken to ensure that a response to a release will be implemented in a proper and timely manner.



PURPOSE FOR UPDATING RMP



The Facility is submitting this to reflect the most recent update and review of the RMP since it's acquisition by Helena. The RMP was revised to the RMP standards implemented by Helena.  All RMP Facility details are reflected in both the EPA RMP Submit report and the Facility Risk Management Plan Program Document (RMPr).





FACILITY



The Facility is a retail agricultural chemical facility and operates one (1) covered process that includes Storage and Handling of anhydrous ammonia.  Anhydrous ammonia is transported to the Facility via a commercial tanker truck and then transferred to one (1) 8,000-gallon stationary pressure vessel. The commercial tanker truck operator (Contractor) performs these transfer operations.



The Facility stores the anhydrous ammonia in the on-site stationary pressure vessel an

d then

transfers the anhydrous ammonia from the pressure vessel to nurse tanks at point of retail sale to

the end user (e.g. the farmer). This Facility owns and operates (8) 1,500-gallon nurse tanks and

(30) 1,000-gallon nurse tanks. Trained Facility Operators perform the transfer operation in accordance with the RMPr accident prevention program.



OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



Worst case and alternative case consequence analyses were completed for the single covered

process that is operated at this Facility. The covered process includes anhydrous ammonia Storage

and Handling. The worst case scenario release for the Retail Facility assumes that all the contents

in the largest single storage tank are released. For this Facility, the largest vessel is an 8,000-gallon stationary pressure vessel. The release was modeled as if the ammonia tank was punctured on the side at the ground level. The resulting release of ammonia was modeled as a ground level horizontal jet.



The alternative (or more likely to occur) scenario was completed for the storage and handling

covered process as well. The alternative release for the Storage and Handling assumes a 30-second release from a ruptured 2-inch transfer hose caused by an impact from a vehicle or some other source on the liquid ammonia transfer hose during a loading or unloading operation. Active mitigation considered in this release scenario includes the activation of a backflow check valve, excess flow valves, and emergency shutoff valves on the storage tank side of the bulkhead, and operating procedures that the Facility uses to safeguard ammonia transfer operations.



ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM



The Manager implements the risk management planning process at this Facility. The Manager is assisted by other Facility staff, as directed. The Manager is responsible for ensuring that Facility Staff are properly trained in the implementation of the Prevention Program which includes Safety Information, Hazard Analysis

, Operating Procedures, Training, Maintenance, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigations, and Emergency Contingency Plans.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



This is a non-responding Facility. The Facility has coordinated emergency response activities with

its local emergency response agency and local fire department. 



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



An incident involving anhydrous ammonia occurred in 2015.  This information is provided in Section 6 of the EPA RMP Submit Report.



CONCLUSION



The Risk Management Plan implemented by the Facility complies with the requirements of the Clean

Air Act, Section 112(r). The RMP will be updated as the Facility adds, deletes, or changes processes. The Emergency Response Program has been coordinated with the local Fire Department and LEPC.



NOTE: Sections 4, 5, and 7 of the standard RMP produced by EPA's RMP Submit Program are

not applicable to this Facility.
